entry.et: Middle English, cork, bark, probably from Middle Dutch *kurk or Middle Low German korck, from Old Spanish alcorque, ultimately from dialect Arabic qurq, from Latin quercus oak fir

def.dt: :the elastic tough outer tissue of the cork oak that is used especially for stoppers and insulation
:a usually cork stopper for a bottle or jug
:to furnish or fit with cork or a cork
:to stop up with a cork cork a bottle
:to blacken with burnt cork corked faces
county SW Ireland in Munster area 2880 square miles (7459 square kilometers), pop 447,829
city & port, its ✽, at head of Cork harbor pop 123,062
:an oak (Quercus suber) of southern Europe and northern Africa that is the source of the cork of commerce
